data.title: But for One Shell: An American Story
data.meta_description: Many people in the years since it happen had wondered what would happen in the magazine at Fort McHenry didn't explode. Or if General Ross hadn't fallen in...
data.text:
September 14 1814: A Shell from an unknown British warship found the power magazine at Fort McHenry. This shell detonated the magazine. The force of the blast destroyed Fort McHenry.

General Samuel Smith hearing the guns going silent withdrew his force of 10,000 out of Baltimore and took up blocking positions outside city the city and outside the range of the Royal Navy.

Colonel Arthur Brooke could see at first light that Americans had withdrawn from Baltimore in good order and outnumbered him 2 to 1. Because of this he refused to commit his ground troops to burn Baltimore like had happen in Washington DC 3 weeks earlier.

Admiral Alexander Cochrane decided since his ships were outside the range of the American artillery, to bombardment Baltimore. His ships moved into position, and began the bombardment around 5pm local time.

September 15 1814: 17 hours in to bombardment the power magazine on HMS Tonnant exploded. Not knowing what cause the magazine on the Tonnant to explode, Admiral Cochrane decided to with draw his fleet.

January 8 1815: The Treaty of Ghent is signed. The treaty restored a status quo ante bellum between the United States of America and the British Empire.

January 8 1815: The Battle of New Orleans: The British are soundly defended, by General Andrew Jackson. The British take 500 death including Generals Edward Pakenham and John Keane, plus they took another 1,500 wounded. After losing their commanders, the British soldiers lose their nerve and turn and run. The remaining British forces under General John Lambert would withdraw and sail back to Jamaica.

January 13-14 1815: An American force at Fort Peter number 170, almost totally militia broke and ran after the British navy fired on their positions. They lost 4 men and took another 8 wounded, the British took no losses in the short battle. They leveled Fort Peter, and looted the nearby town of St. Marys. The British looted from private citizens as well all public buildings. If not for the actions Admiral George Cockburn the British would have put St Marys to the torch.

January 15 1815: Commodore Stephen Decatur seeing 5 British frigates outside New York harbor, decided that he wouldn't be able to break out, so he keeps the USS President in port.

February 8-15 1815: Second Fort Bowyer: A force of a thousand men under General John Lambert try to take Fort Bowyer: But the American force under Colonel William Lawrence, number 475 hold out. After seven days of trying to take Fort Bowyer General Lambert withdrew again. The British lost 24 killed, 38 wounded with the Americans taking only 17 wounded.

February 20 1815: The USS Constitution in patrol in the Atlantic ran into two smaller British Warships, the HMS Cyane and HMS Levant. In the battle that followed the crew of the Constitution was able to take both British ships as prizes.

March 1 1815: The US Senate unanimously approved the Treaty of Ghent.

As the war ended Americans saw time and time again their militia units break and run. Only the regular army put up a fight every time. They also saw two of their important cities(Washington and Baltimore) destroyed by a nation that had a much larger navy against their smaller mostly coastal force. By and large every American vowed this would never happen again.

June 15 1815: Congress passed the Naval Reform Act of 1815, which is signed by James Madison. The Naval Act of 1815, would establish the US Naval Academy. It would also set standards for promotions of officers. The days of buying and selling commissions in the navy also was ended with this act.

June 17 1815: A force under the command of Commodore Stephen Decatur who is on his flagship the USS President attacks a frigate of the Algerian Navy. Decatur's force eases takes the frigate in the battle. The American victory was the flagship of the Algerian Navy.

June 19 1815: Decatur and his force spot another ship of the Algerian Navy, this one being a brig. The Americans under Decatur again perform well and take the Algerian Brig as a war trophy. Marking the second such victory for Decatur in the past three days.

June 24 1815: Decatur's force 7 ships begin a blockade of Algiers.

June 26 1815: Decatur's forces is joined by Commodore William Bainbridge's force of 8 ships, who add his ships to the blockade of Algiers.

July 1 1815: Decatur and Bainbridge force The Dey of Algiers, who was under the threat of the American ships destroying Algiers, to sign a peace treaty. Under this treaty all Americans held by the Dey of Algiers were to be freed and their ships released. The treaty sign would granted the USA full shipping rights within the Mediterranean Sea. In return to US would return the two Algerian warships it had taken as war trophies and a onetime payment of 7,500 dollars with the understanding there would be no more tribute would be paid.

July 2 1815: No one is sure what caused it to happen, if orders were misunderstood or it out of hate, but Algerian troops kill the 10 American captives as well as a number of European captives who had been set freed by the treaty sign the day before.

Decatur who watched this massacre happened ordered his fastest warship to return to Gibraltar with orders to keep the two Algerian warships in dock there and let the other Europeans know of this massacre. He would wait for at least one other nation to join him before he destroyed Algiers.

July 9 1815: The USS Constitution reaches Gibraltar and informs the Dutch and British who were in dock there of the massacre in Algiers 9 days earlier. To do hard feelings of the War of 1812 still bring there only the Dutch force of 5 ships under Vice Admiral Theodorus Frederik van Capellen agreed to help the Americans to end the Barbary Pirates run of terror in the Mediterranean.

July 19 1815: The USS Constitution and the Dutch under Admiral van Capellen join the forces under Decatur and Bainbridge. The terms to the Dey of Algiers was simple, free all Christian slaves, repay all of the tribute which had been paid in the past 5 year, and stop enslaving Christians. It stated the ships that had been taken by Decatur were to become ships of the USN. The Dey of Algiers refused the terms.

July 20 1815: The joint American-Dutch forces bombard Algiers of 10 hours. In that time the joint force destroys the bulk of the Algerian navy and defense positions. But One American becomes so damaged in the battle it has to be scuttled. Also a Dutch warship is lost in the battle. But the Algerians take main more casualties than the joint American-Dutch fleet.

July 21 1815: Decatur sends a officer under a flag of truces to meet with the Dey of Algiers. It was a simple message, agree to the terms or have your city destroyed. This was a bluff on Decatur's part, because the Americans as well as the Dutch were out of power.

But the Dey of Algiers fails to call this bluff and agrees to the terms that he rejected on two days ago.

August 13 1815: The Militia Reform Act of 1815 is passed and signed into law by President James Madison. The Militia Reform Act changed the way the US handed the militia. Every Militia officer would have to have at least 2 years of training with the regular army before be granted a commission in his home state's militia. It also stated that all enlisted personnel would have to undergo a two month training course as well.

October 12 1815: John C Calhoun who was representing the 6th district of South Carolina is thrown from his horse. The force of the impact broke Calhoun's neck, he died a few hours after being thrown from his horse.

November 29 1815: The final major piece of military reform was signed into law. The Army Officer Reform Act, like the Naval Act of 1815 set standards for promotions of officers as well as ending the days of buying and selling commissions.

January 9 1816: The Treaty of Algeria was ratified by the US Senate.

February 14 1816: The charter for the Second Bank of the United States is signed into law. In this charter there were a system of checks and balances to keep fraud and corruption down. The charter was good for 25 years.

March 19 1816: Delaware Governor John Clark and his house following the example of John Dickinson sign a bill into law to free the slaves within Delaware. No slaves would be free right away, but it was now illegal to buy or sell slaves within Delaware. All children who were slaves would be given their freedom when they reaching their 19 birthday. Every other slave would be freed within the next 25 years. The state would pay full value if the owners asked for it.

May 1 1816: The Keel to the USS George Washington is laid. The USS George Washington was to be second rate ship of the line armed with 90 cannons. When finished she would become the flagship of the USN.

July 27 1816: The Battle of Negro Fort: American forces under General Andrew Jackson attack and destroy what Americans had started to call the Negro Fort. Jackson destroys the fort within a few hours. This attack marked the start the First Seminole War.

December 4 1816: Americans elect James Monroe a Democratic-Republican to be their next president. His changer Rufus King a Federalist from New York was soundly defeated. Monroe won 16 states to King's three.(77,921 to 32,791)

December 9 1816: Indiana is admitted to the Union as a Free State.
